did.unittitle: Margaret Hill Collins papers regarding Suburban Fair Housing and Community Support Corporation
did.repository: Swarthmore College, Friends Historical Library Swarthmore, Pennsylvania 19081-1399 U.S.A.

bioghist.p: Margaret Hill Collins (1908-2006) was educated at Sarah Lawrence College and the University of California at Berkeley, and later received a master's degree in social work from Bryn Mawr College. She was a member of Haverford Meeting. In 1956, Collins formed Friends Suburban Housing, a real estate agency that worked to integrate housing on the Main Line. In 1963, its name was changed to Suburban Fair Housing (SFH). Collins was executive secretary of the company, which ended operation in 1976 as fair housing laws were strengthened. Later, Collins worked with the Community Support Corporation (CSC) to rehabilitate houses for low-income families. She also produced a three-volume genealogy of the Collins family.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Margaret Hill Collins related to her work with Community Support Corporation and Suburban Fair Housing. Materials include: correspondence, minutes, and financial records of the CSC; documentation of projects performed at individual houses, including estimates, bills and receipts, plans, and bills of sale; drafts of proposals for several cooperative housing initiatives in the early 1950s; typed articles and prayers by Collins; memorial booklets; newspaper clippings; awards and certificates of appreciation; brochures of SFH; and photographs of houses sold through SFH. The collection also includes a small amount of genealogical material and poems and writings of Collins's cousin Hilda Worthington Smith.
